discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is the right answer. This is not wireshark.

comments.content: but ip.host == 192.168.0.125 is not a valid Wireshark filter. Wireshark uses ip.addr to refer to both source and destination IP addresses, not ip.host.

No, D is correct: tcp.port == 25 and ip.host == 192.168.0.125.
Syntax of C does not work in Wireshark (it is not tcpdump!) and moreover C does not specifi TCP, which is requirement in the question.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is the right answer

questions.question_text: What is the correct PCAP filter to capture all TCP traffic going to or from host 192.168.0.125 on port 25?

discussion.content:
NetStumbler is one of the best valued tools by the users for a few years now to detect local area networks (WLAN) with the standards 802.11b, 802.11a and 802.11g.

The program does a brief check showing all the existing networks in the area that the receptor can receive and which state each one is in.

NetStumbler also allows us to verify that our network is correctly configured studying the network coverage in different places. It can also calculate the interferences that other networks can cause on our signal or detect non-authorised access points.

In this sense, the program can also be quite useful to determine the direction the antenna should be in to receive a better coverage.

questions.question_text: Which tool would be used to collect wireless packet data?

questions.question_text: After gaining access to the password hashes used to protect access to a web based application, knowledge of which cryptographic algorithms would be useful to gain access to the application?

choices.D: LM hashes are not generated when the password length exceeds 15 characters.
choices.C: Uppercase characters in the password are converted to lowercase.
choices.A: LM hashes consist in 48 hexadecimal characters.
choices.B: LM hashes are based on AES128 cryptographic standard.

comments.content: Not C, everything is converted to uppercase
